Comments_List: Improvement of critical reading skills & knowledge about the field of social perception more generally
This course really informed how I think about the ties between cognition and perception. I've also become more comfortable discussing my thoughts in a larger group setting.

I learned 1) what social perception is, 2) criticisms of the field, 3) progress that's been made in the field, 4) common methods used to study visual perception, visual attention, facial processing, and other phenomena that fall under the umbrellas of "perception" and more specifically "social perception."
Gives you a good background of the different topics and issues in social perception, which itself is such an interesting intersection of two different areas of psychology!

learnt about research on social perception
heated discussions regarding the topics
skills of critical thinking
I learned a lot about perception, and the course inspired some ideas for future research.

I learned a great deal about how to critically evaluate research in both vision science and social psychology. I learned a lot about how to integrate two interesting and often distinct fields of work to learn more about both
I liked that we read both "good" papers and "bad" papers which forced us to think critically about what makes a good paper and good data. I liked the discussion session format.
Overall, this is a very strong course. At times, we ran low on time, and I wished we could have delved deeper into some of the readings.

This course's major strength is its instructor. Brian Scholl is truly excellent. He is an extremely thorough and thoughtful communicator, and he's clearly an expert in this field. For every discussion, he prepared a considerable amount of content to incorporate. Also, for each discussion, he carefully read our required responses and tied them into the flow of conversation.  

I have only 2 criticisms, both relatively small: 1) There should be fewer readings, so that we can actually discuss what we read in detail, and 2) There should be a lecture component to the class, along with a discussion period, so that we can hear about all the points Brian wants to make (which are all awesome) AND discuss the readings in greater detail.
Absolutely an amazing course. It was very structured and purposeful. Learned a lot.

Great selection of readings, though "social perception" was a bit of a misnomer: we had one class on olfaction, but everything else was about visual processing, rather than all modalities. There was plenty in visual perception to go through, though, so that's not much of a negative.

Strengths: a lot of thought went into the papers we talked about, brian did a great job of leading class discussions, and i loved the idea of bringing in additional readings each week, i think it added a lot to class discussions

Weaknesses: we could occasionally get side tracked, but it wasnt too much of a problem.

Yes, absolutely. Great course, great selection of readings, interesting lectures, and an opportunity to ask questions.

If you have any interest in social psychology, absolutely. It will give you ideas about how to test your research ideas in a more rigorous way and connect it to other areas of cognitive science, and I think it's a good protective against being too walled off in your work.
